Deleting Local Files: stcmd delete-local

Use stcmd delete-local to delete files from a working folder. You can delete files that are under version control, as well as files that are not in the application. This action does not remove any files from version control; it merely reduces the amount of data stored on your workstation in a working folder. If you are deleting files based on their application status, it is a good idea to use stcmd update-status first.

Syntax

stcmd delete-local -p "projectSpecifier" [-pwdfile "filePath"] [-cmp] [-csf] [-encrypt encryptionType] [-is] [-q] [-x] [-stop] [-rp "folderPath" | -fp "folderPath"] [-cfgl "labelName" | -cfgp "stateName" | -cfgd "asOfDate"] [-filter "fileStatus"] [files...]

Example

The following example uses stcmd delete-local to delete some files from the working folder for the application folder named SourceCode. SourceCode is a child of the root folder StarDraw (in the StarDraw view of the StarDraw project). This example deletes all files that are not under version control. Those files have the file status Not In View.

stcmd delete-local -p "JMarsh:password@Orion:49201/StarDraw/StarDraw/SourceCode"
-filter "N" "*"

 

For more information, see Using Common stcmd Options.
